nodes.text: Principal Component Analysis based eigenface approach can provide a practical, fast, and simple solution for automatic face recognition in constrained environments
The eigenface method represents each training image as a linear combination of eigenvectors (eigenfaces) obtained from the covariance matrix of the training set
Recognition is performed by projecting a test image onto the subspace spanned by selected eigenfaces and classifying by minimum Euclidean distance between weight vectors
PCA reduces dimensionality by keeping only the K eigenvectors with largest eigenvalues, omitting low eigenvalue eigenfaces that explain little characteristic variance
The implemented system in MATLAB was tested on a small database (ETE-07 series, RUET) consisting of 36 images of 18 persons and on various image formats (BMP, PNG, JPEG)
The eigenface approach is simple, fast, and relatively insensitive to small or gradual facial changes, but requires frontal, centered, similarly sized face images for good performance

Computational optimization: compute eigenvectors of the M by M matrix L = A transpose times A (where M is number of training faces) to obtain the M largest eigenvectors of the full covariance matrix efficiently

Training pipeline: collect centered same-size face images, vectorize images, compute average face, subtract mean to form matrix A, compute covariance-related matrix, extract eigenfaces, keep top K eigenvectors to form face space

Testing pipeline: detect and crop face from test image, project normalized test face onto eigenface basis to get weight vector, compute Euclidean distances to training weight vectors, assign class with minimum distance
Experimental results: system successfully recognized human faces and worked better under different face orientations in the tested dataset
Experimental setup included examples with same pose (results 1 and 2) and with pose variation (results 3 and 4) to evaluate robustness to pose changes
Limitation: performance degrades with variations in image size and when faces are not vertical frontal views; algorithm is best suited to constrained conditions
Conclusion: PCA eigenface approach gave very good classification on the tested constrained database and is a practical solution for face recognition under constrained conditions
Future work: extend system to real-time video, increase database size, handle varying image sizes, and compare PCA performance with other face recognition methods
